nodes.text: IT projects present a hidden, high-risk profile because a disproportionate number produce extreme cost and schedule overruns (Black Swans) that can sink companies and careers
Across a sample of IT projects the average cost overrun was 27%
The distribution of overruns has a fat tail: one in six projects was a Black Swan with average cost overrun of 200% and schedule overrun of almost 70%
Method: largest global study of IT change initiatives examining 1,471 projects comparing planned budgets and estimated benefits with actual costs and results
Claim: Focusing on average overruns conceals the real risk because extreme outliers (Black Swans) cause disproportionate damage
Evidence - Levi Strauss: a planned under 5 million dollar SAP migration led to $192.5 million charge, order fulfillment failures, and CIO resignation

Evidence - Multiple high-impact failures: Kmart IT projects contributed to bankruptcy; Auto Windscreens and Toll Collect projects caused company failure or large government losses; Hong Kong airport glitches cost estimated $600 million
Claim: Mismanaged large IT projects can cost top managers their jobs and can sink entire corporations or cause major public losses
Claim: Companies already facing financial pressure, eroding margins, or demanding debt servicing are especially vulnerable to catastrophic impacts from an out-of-control IT project

Recommendation / Method: Perform a stress test asking whether the company can absorb a single largest tech project exceeding budget by 400% with only 25 to 50 percent of projected benefits realized, and whether 15 percent of medium projects could exceed estimates by 200 percent

Recommendation: To avoid Black Swans break large projects into limited-size modules, plan contingencies, resist scope creep, use reference class forecasting, and treat initiatives as business not purely technical endeavors

Evidence - Emirates NBD case: after merger a major core banking project finished with only 7% schedule slip and 18% cost overrun by sticking to schedule, resisting scope change, modularizing, assembling the right team, and retaining staff

Context / Limitation: The sample averaged project cost of 167 million dollars, largest 33 billion; sample drew heavily on public agencies (92 percent) and US-based projects (83 percent), though authors found little difference across sectors and regions

Claim: Increasing embedding of software into products and limited implementation expertise among engineers and managers increases the risk of configuration and integration failures (illustrated by Airbus A380 wiring and software version mismatch)
